headline: The Thirsty Man and the Flower
description: A parable woven on the loom: a wanderer seeks water, finds a radiant flower, drinks its soothing nectar, and learns the cost of comfort that consumes. The lesson is threaded back into the cloth.
author: Aleksandr Agnitio
resonantThread: Parable Loom; Wanderer parables; Ousia Bloom phases
whyItMatters: Parable Loom is where lessons are spun into pattern. This tale warns how nectar can numb and bind, and stitches the counter-principle: thirst must be met from the inner well.

motifMap.meaning: Bond forged in harm; mutually wounding tie
Loss of vigilance; dream-trap of denial
Facing lack honestly; beginning of inner well

articleExcerpt: He learned the loom’s lesson: nothing outside would end his thirst. Only from within might he draw a drink to heal his aching throat.

sourceFragments.quote: For 40 years he wandered searching for clean, cool water—
In the garden he found a flower of radiance…
A deep, magical sleep would overcome him;
Only from within might he find a drink to heal his aching throat.
